Greensboro NC April 27 1865 Comdg Officer Chester SC Gen Johnson desires you will publish the following order – Unattached officers and men of the Army and officers of the Navy within the country of the Chattahoochie river may also accept the terms of the convention Hd Qrs of the Army of Tenn Near Gainsboro, N.C. April 26 1865 Gen Order No 183 By the virtue of a Military Convention made on the 26th by Maj Gen W. T. Sherman U.S.A. and J. E. Johnson C.S.A. the officers & men of this army are to bind themselves not to take up arms against the United States until properly relieved from their obligation and shall secure guarantee from the United States against molestation by the U.S. authorities so long as they observe that obligation and the Laws in force where they reside. For these objects duplicate muster rolls will be made immediately and after distribution of the necessary papers the troops will march under their officers to their respective state and their be disbanded all retaining personal property. The object of this convention is pacification to the extent of the authority of the commanders who made it Events in Virginia which broke every hope of success by war imposed on to Grant the duty of sparring the blood of this gallant army and sparring our country from further devastation and our people from ruin. Signed J. E. Johnson Gen
Hd Qrs Mid Div of the Mississippi In the Field Raliegh NC Ap 27 Special Order No 15 The Gen Comdy announces a further –
[Page 2 of 2] Suspension of hostilities and a final agreement with Gen Johnson which terminated the war as to the forces under his command and the country East of the Chattahoochie river. Copies of the terms of the convention will be furnished Maj. Gen Lehofield Gelman & Wilson who are specifically charged with the execution of its detail in N.C. The Dept of the South and at Macon and Westine Georgia. Capt Joseph Myers ordnance Dept W. S. it is hereby designated to receive the arms &c at Greensboro and any Comdy officer of the Port may receive the arms of any detachment and see that they are properly stored and accounted for Gen Lehofield will procure at once the necessary blanks and supply the other army commanders that uniformity may prevail and great care must be taken that the terms and litigations on our part be fulfilled with the most scrupulous fidelity whilst those imposed upon our hitherto enemies be received in a spirit becoming a brave and generous people. Army Commanders may at once loan to the inhabitants such of the captured mules horses wagons and vehicles as can be spared from immediate use and the Commd’y Genl of Armies may issue provisions, animals and any public supplies that can be spared to relieve present wards and to encourage inhabitants to renew their peaceful pursuits and to restore feelings of friendship among our fellow – citizens and countrymen foraging will forthwith cease and where necessity or long marches compel the taking of forage or provisions or any kind of private property compensation will be made on the spot. – or when disbursing officers are not provided with funds, vouchers will be given in proper form payable at the nearest military depot. By order of Maj Gen W. T. Sherman (@gd) T. M. Dayton (@sd) Archer Anderson A Alsnd Lt-Col & A A G
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Communication from J. S. Johnson in North Carolina containing Special Order No. 5 from General J. E. Johnston, C. S. A., commanding the officers and soldiers of the Confederate Army and Navy not to take up arms against the United States, and announcing a guarantee from the United States against molestation by the U. S. authorities. It includes orders on provisions and the issuance of vouchers to citizens. Intended to be published.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On April 26, 1865, General Joseph E. Johnston surrendered to William T. Sherman in North Carolina. Special orders are comprised of commands related to specific actions to be taken within the units of troops specified in the order. Such orders can involve movements, actions, and transfers.
